sequence.notes: Selective protection of the primary alcohol with TBSCl.
Regioselective formation of a tributylstannyl ether from a secondary alcohol mediated by dibutyltin oxide.
Selective benzylation of a stannyl ether in the presence of a free hydroxyl group. The tributylstannyl group is replaced by a benzyl group.
Mesylation of a secondary alcohol to form a mesylate ester.
Iodo-methoxy addition to a dihydropyran catalyzed by NIS. The double bond undergoes electrophilic addition with iodine and methanol. The product has four chiral centers.
Reductive removal of iodide from a cyclic ether using tributyltin hydride and AIBN as a radical initiator.
Cleavage of the anomeric methoxy group of the pyranose and formation of a 1,3-dithiane ring from the linear product of ring opening.
Oxidative cleavage of a 1,2-diol to an aldehyde using lead tetraacetate.

Aldehyde undergoes Wittig olefination with ethyl (triphenylphosphoranylidene)acetate to form an alpha,beta-unsaturated ethyl ester. Stereochemistry at the existing chiral centers is maintained, and a new trans (E) double bond is formed.
Allylic substitution of a mesylate with a methyl group, accompanied by double bond migration.
Hydrogenation of a Z-alkene to form a saturated chain, retaining existing stereochemistry.
Oxidative deprotection of a 1,3-dithiane to form an aldehyde.
Nozaki-Hiyama-Kishi coupling of an aldehyde with an E-vinyl iodide to form a new C-C bond and a secondary alcohol. Stereochemistry at newly formed alcohol is (R).

substeps.notes: Hydroiodination of but-2-ynoic acid to form (2E)-3-iodo-2-methylbut-2-enoic acid.
Methylation of 2-iodo-2-butenoic acid with diazomethane to form the corresponding methyl ester.
Reduction of an alpha,beta-unsaturated methyl ester to the corresponding allylic alcohol.
Formation of an O-mesylate from a primary alcohol.

sequence.notes: Oxidation of a secondary alcohol to a ketone using Dess-Martin periodinane.
Deprotection of benzyl ether to hydroxyl group (3 steps indicated in image)
Stereoselective reduction of a ketone to a secondary alcohol.
Ester hydrolysis of ethyl ester to carboxylic acid using lithium hydroxide. Stereochemistry and alkene geometry are preserved.
Intramolecular esterification (lactone formation) of a carboxylic acid with a hydroxyl group.
Methylation of a secondary alcohol to a methyl ether using silver oxide and iodomethane.
Base-catalyzed solvolysis of a lactone in methanol leading to a methyl ester and an alcohol.
The secondary alcohol is protected as a tert-butyldimethylsilyl (TBS) ether using TBSOTf and 2,6-lutidine. All existing stereocenters and the E-alkene configuration are maintained.
Methyl ester reduced to primary alcohol using DIBAL.
Selective triethylsilyl ether formation at the primary alcohol.
Formation of a β-hydroxy sulfone intermediate from an allylic sulfone and an aldehyde.

substeps.notes: Alkylation of a secondary alcohol to form a benzyl ether, retaining stereochemistry.
(2 steps)
Oxidation of a primary alcohol to an aldehyde, with retention of stereochemistry at the adjacent chiral center.
Stereoselective formation of a dihydropyranone via reaction of an alpha-chiral aldehyde with a silyloxydiene.
Ketone reduced to allylic alcohol using DIBAL. Stereochemistry of the new alcohol center is consistent with the existing stereocenters (OH is wedged/up).
Acid-catalyzed etherification of the secondary alcohol at C4 of the pyran ring with isopropanol, proceeding with inversion of stereochemistry. The benzyloxy and methyl side chain remain unchanged.
Catalytic hydrogenation of the dihydropyran ring to a tetrahydropyran. Explicit stereochemistry for C5 in the product was inferred from the drawn structure and added to the SMILES.
(2 steps)
Thioketalization of an isopropyl glycoside (cyclic acetal) to form a 1,3-dithiane with simultaneous pyranose ring opening, yielding a diol.
Oxidative cleavage of a 1,2-diol using Lead(IV) acetate to yield an aldehyde, with retention of stereochemistry at other chiral centers.
Wittig olefination of an aldehyde to form an alpha,beta-unsaturated ethyl ester.
DIBAL-H reduction of an α,β-unsaturated ester to a primary alcohol, preserving the double bond and 1,3-dithiane protecting group.
Protection of a primary alcohol as a TBDPS silyl ether.
Oxidative cleavage of a 1,3-dithiane to yield an aldehyde.
Reduction of an aldehyde to a primary alcohol using sodium borohydride. The TBDPS protecting group and the alkene are unaffected.
Primary alcohol converted to pivalate ester.
Deprotection of the TBDPS ether to a primary alcohol using HF, while the pivalate ester remains intact.
Primary alcohol oxidation to aldehyde

sequence.notes: Acetylation of a secondary alcohol to form an acetate ester.
DBU-mediated elimination of the acetate group to form an extended conjugated triene system.
Reduction of a pivaloate ester to a primary alcohol using DIBAL.
Reductive cleavage of a phenyl sulfone group using sodium amalgam to form an extended conjugated tetraene system.
Oxidation of a primary alcohol to an aldehyde. The reported yield of 67% is over 3 steps.

Aldehyde group is converted to a secondary alcohol with an added methoxymethyl group. There is a clear discrepancy between the drawn reagent (lithium propoxide) and the observed transformation (addition of CH2OMe group, implying a reagent like LiCH2OMe). The provided reagent SMILES was junk.
Oxidation of a secondary alcohol to a ketone.
Selective deprotection of primary triethylsilyl (TES) ether to primary alcohol using acetic acid. The tert-butyldimethylsilyl (TBS) ether remains intact.
Primary alcohol is oxidized to an aldehyde.
Stereoselective aldol addition of a chiral sulfoxide auxiliary to an aldehyde, forming a new beta-hydroxy sulfoxide.

substeps.notes: Acid-catalyzed esterification of piperidine-2-carboxylic acid with isobutene/water to form the tert-butyl ester.
Acylation of a secondary piperidine amine with (phenylthio)acetic acid using EDC as a coupling agent.
Oxidation of a thioether to a sulfoxide.

sequence.notes: Dess-Martin oxidation of secondary alcohol to ketone, accompanied by the removal/transformation of the chiral sulfoxide auxiliary adjacent to the original alcohol.

Deprotection of a silyl ether (TBS) to a hydroxyl group, followed by an intramolecular cyclization that forms a tetrahydropyran ring. Concurrently, the tert-butyl ester attached to the piperidine is converted to a tert-butyl ether.
Acid-catalyzed hydrolysis of the tert-butyl ester to a carboxylic acid.
Esterification of a carboxylic acid with allyl bromide to form an allyl ester.
Protection of a hydroxyl group with trimethylsilyl (TMS) ether.
Selective deprotection of allyl ester to carboxylic acid.
Esterification reaction between a carboxylic acid and an alcohol using DCC/DMAP to form a large macrocyclic ester.

substeps.notes: Addition of methanol to the double bond of a dihydropyran, forming a methyl pyranoside. The double bond at C3-C4 is reduced, and a methoxy group is introduced at C2 with inversion of stereochemistry at that carbon.
Formation of a 3,6-O-benzylidene acetal (a 1,3-dioxepane ring fused to the pyranose) via condensation of methyl alpha-D-glucoside derivative with benzaldehyde.
Methylation of the secondary alcohol at C3, catalyzed by sodium hydride with methyl iodide as the methylating agent.
Regioselective opening of a benzylidene acetal using NBS and BaCO3 to form a bromohydrin and benzoate.
Hydrolysis of a benzoate ester to a hydroxyl group.
An E2 elimination of HBr forms an exocyclic alkene, and a hydroxyl group is deprotonated by NaH and subsequently benzylated by BnBr.
A Ferrier rearrangement of a glycal-like structure, involving hydrolysis of the anomeric acetal and rearrangement to form a cyclohexanone derivative with a hydroxyl group.
Dehydration of a secondary alcohol to form an alpha,beta-unsaturated ketone.
Luche reduction of an alpha,beta-unsaturated ketone to the corresponding allylic alcohol, with stereoselective formation of the hydroxyl group pointing up.
Esterification of an alcohol with a carboxylic acid using EDC and DMAP.
Formation of a silyl enol ether from an ester, likely via deprotonation with LDA and trapping with TBSCl. The double bond of the enol ether is formed with Z-geometry.
Ireland Claisen rearrangement of an enol silyl ether to a silyl ester, creating two new chiral centers on the cyclohexane ring.

No apparent chemical transformation between reactant and product; structures are identical. The reaction might represent a stability test or workup under basic conditions where all protecting groups are stable.

The reaction involves an oxidation and subsequent lactonization. The 'TBSO2C' group in the reactant screenshot was interpreted as an 'OTBS' group (tert-butyl-dimethylsilyl ether), consistent with the provided initial SMILES and the formation of a lactone at that position in the product. The stereochemistry of all chiral centers appears to be preserved, with the relative configurations matching the reactant structure and the new lactone ring formation maintaining the stereochemistry of the involved carbons. The silyl protecting group was corrected from triisopropylsilyl (TIPS) to tert-butyldimethylsilyl (TBS) as indicated by 'TBSO' in the screenshot.
Reduction of the cyclohexene double bond.
Diisobutylaluminium hydride (DIBAL) reduction of a gamma-lactone to a hemiacetal.

Suarez reaction involving furanose ring opening, iodination, and oxidation of the anomeric carbon to an aldehyde. The wavy bond for the anomeric carbon's OH in the reactant and the iodide in the product indicates unspecified stereochemistry at these positions.
Radical deiodination of an alkyl iodide using triphenyltin hydride and AIBN.
Double hydrogenolysis of benzyl ethers to alcohols.
TEMPO-mediated oxidation of a primary alcohol to an aldehyde.
Wittig olefination of an aldehyde to form an E-α,β-unsaturated ester.
Protection of the secondary alcohol on the cyclohexyl ring as a triisopropylsilyl (TIPS) ether. The existing tert-butyldimethylsilyl (TBS) ether, aldehyde, and ethyl ester groups remain unchanged.
Reduction of an α,β-unsaturated ethyl ester to a primary allylic alcohol and an aldehyde to a secondary alcohol.
Manganese dioxide mediated oxidation of a primary alcohol to an aldehyde.

sequence.notes: Deprotection of TBS and TMS protecting groups to hydroxyls using TBAF and acetic acid.

Oxidation of a secondary alcohol (adjacent to the cyclohexyl group) to a ketone. The aldehyde group and the tertiary alcohol remain unchanged. All methoxy groups are abbreviated to [OMe]. The OTIPS (triisopropylsilyloxy) protecting group shown in the screenshot is missing from the heavy atom composition (no Si atom) in the provided input SMILES for both reactant and product. It has not been added to avoid major structural modification beyond simple correction.

The aldehyde group of the reactant is transformed into a new chain segment containing a hydroxyl, a methoxy, and a ketone group. This transformation facilitates the closure of the macrolactone ring. The OTIPS and OMe protecting groups remain unchanged.
Deprotection of a TIPS ether to a hydroxyl group using HF-pyridine.
